1:31 p.m. Trump is giving a speech to an inauguration crowd after being introduced by JD Vance.

"You're a younger, far more beautiful audience than the one I just spoke to," he joked. "I want to keep it off the record."

Trump also addressed Biden's pre-emptive pardons of his family members and others hours before the inauguration, noting they were "very, very guilty of very bad crimes."

1:30 p.m. A group of men clad in the garb of the Proud Boys marched through the streets of Washington shortly after Trump was sworn in. A handful of counter protesters yelled through megaphones that they were "losers."

1:25 p.m. Trump administration shuts down CBP One

The new Trump administration has already shut down CBP One, a government mobile app that previously helped migrants submit information and schedule appointments at ports of entry.

"Effective January 20, 2025, the functionalities of CBP One that previously allowed undocumented aliens to submit advance information and schedule appointments at eight southwest border ports of entry is no longer available, and existing appointments have been cancelled," an alert on the app's website reads.

Roughly 270,000 Mexican migrants were waiting to get an appointment through the app before it shuttered, CBS reports. As of Jan. 16, nearly 919,000 migrants were allowed into the States through the app.

1:16 p.m. Trudeau congratulates Trump

In a social media post, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau congratulated Trump on his inauguration. "We have the chance to work together again -- to create more jobs and prosperity for both our nations," Trudeau said.

In his speech, Trump did not mention Canada but reiterated his threat of tariffs on foreign nations. Trump had previously threatened 25 per cent tariffs against Canada.

FBI acting chief Paul Abbate says he's retiring

Paul Abbate, who became the FBI's acting director following the departure of Christopher Wray, is retiring from the bureau, according to an email he sent to senior executives that was obtained by The Associated Press on Monday.

Abbate had been expected to run the FBI while Senate confirmation proceedings get underway for Kash Patel, who is President Donald Trump's pick for director. But with Abbate's retirement effective Monday, when Trump took office, it was not immediately clear who would fill that role.

1:02 p.m. Government site gets makeover

The whitehouse.gov website got a makeover, welcoming visitors with a video glorifying Trump to soaring orchestral music before giving way to a landing page boasting that "America is back" in large lettering and an image of Trump.

"Every single day I will be fighting for you with every breath in my body," an accompanying caption reads. "I will not rest until we have delivered the strong, safe and prosperous America that our children deserve and that you deserve. This will truly be the golden age of America."

12:43 p.m. Carrie Underwood's performance beset by technical difficulties

Carrie Underwood's highly-anticipated performance at Trump's inauguration did not exactly go as planned.

After being introduced, the Grammy-winning country singer stood in awkward silence caused by technical difficulties as she waited for the musical track to begin. After about a minute, Underwood could be seen mouthing the words "I can just sing it," before requesting that the audience "help me out here." She then proceeded to perform the song a cappella without further issue.

An eight-time Grammy winner, Underwood, 41, is the highest profile artist slated to perform at Trump's inauguration. Her decision to perform at the inauguration was met with significant negative reactions from her fans, particularly her LGBTQ+ fans. Underwood has not publicly responded to those criticisms.

12:54 p.m. What did Melania Trump wear?

Incoming First Lady Melania Trump, who was mostly shunned by America's fashion establishment during her husband's last term in office, arrived at the church service ahead of her husband's second inauguration in a slim-fit navy silk-and-wool coat and skirt set by American designer Adam Lippes.

Notably, she accessorized it with a flat-brimmed, low-slung hat with white trim by Eric Javits, an American milliner since the 1980s with celebrity clients including Dua Lipa and Lady Gaga. Sitting low on her face Spy vs. Spy-style, the hat is destined to become an instant meme, while preventing the cameras from catching any accidental facial expressions-Melania has been captured seemingly giving side-eye at events in the past.

The choice of Adam Lippes for her outfit seems calculated to show support for a smaller, independent fashion designer. Lippes, who worked for Oscar de la Renta before starting his own label a decade ago, specializes in American sportswear; his dresses run in the $3,000 to $4,000 range. For Trump's first inauguration, Melanie wore a light blue dress by heritage brand Ralph Lauren (also a favourite designer of the Biden family) that drew comparisons to Jackie Kennedy's style.

"Melania's look is restrained, classic, uniform like. It looks like a dramatic governess outfit," said Tracy Richardson, a Canadian image consultant who has dressed clients for the White House, Buckingham Palace, the Oscars, TIFF and the Junos. "The hat is dramatic. But she looks neat. We aren't distracted by what she is wearing." Leanne Delap/Special to the Star

12:53 p.m. Trump stops short of immediately imposing Canadian tariffs

U.S. President Donald Trump has stopped short of immediately imposing his threatened 25-percent tariff on Canadian and Mexican goods.

But in his inaugural address minutes after taking office, Trump left no doubt he has foreign manufacturers and America's allies and competitors in his crosshairs.

He vowed he would set up a new agency to collect tariff revenues, and that he will fill American coffers with tariff and tax revenue from foreign countries, saying he was "saved by God to make America great again."

Trump declared a series of national emergencies to deploy soldiers to the Mexican border, ramp up oil drilling, end electric vehicle mandates, and began what he called "an overhaul" of U.S. trade relations.

12:26 p.m. (updated) Trump promises 'golden age of America'

The close adviser to Trump, owner of the social media platform X and richest man on Earth has a new-found interest in Canada, a ratio of five X followers for every Canadian and the stamina to post dozens of times a day. And he's not afraid to dish out his political opinions online.

Musk weighed in recently when outgoing Prime Minister Justin Trudeau pushed back against Trump's public musings about annexing Canada. Trudeau wrote on X that there "isn't a snowball's chance in hell that Canada would become part of the United States."

Trump swearing-in will move inside Capitol Rotunda because of intense cold

President-elect Donald Trump may take the oath of office from inside the Capitol Rotunda on Monday due to forecasts of intense cold weather.

"The weather forecast for Washington, D.C., with the windchill factor, could take temperatures into severe record lows," Trump posted on his Truth Social platform. "There is an Arctic blast sweeping the Country. I don't want to see people hurt, or injured, in any way."

The Rotunda is prepared as the inclement weather alternative for each inauguration in the event of inclement weather. The swearing-in was last moved indoors in 1985, when President Ronald Reagan began his second term. Monday's forecast calls for the lowest inauguration day temperatures since that day.

Canada ready to respond should tariffs be imposed as soon as Monday

Canada should brace for U.S. tariffs to be imposed as soon as Monday, and if so, Ottawa will be ready to respond immediately, says Foreign Affairs Minister Melanie Joly who held out hope on Friday there's still time to avoid a trade war.

Joly said the federal government estimates the impact, if U.S. President Donald Trump follows through on his threatened 25-percent tariff on all Canadian goods, would be massive. It would increase the cost of living and mean job losses across Canada and in key U.S. states but she refused to provide federal estimates of what the national job losses or the hit to economic activity could be.

"Definitely we have numbers that are highlighting how much this could be devastating," Joly told reporters in a virtual news conference. "The Americans would be starting a trade war against us. And this would be the biggest trade war between Canada and U.S. in decades."

Canada is gearing up to counterattack Trump's tariff threat, Justin Trudeau says

Canada is getting ready to strike back against Donald Trump's tariffs, even though there is dissension in the nation's ranks.

Prime Minister Justin Trudeau emerged from a meeting with all 13 premiers Wednesday armed with a proposal to slap counter-tariffs on up to $150 billion worth of American imports, depending on how far the incoming U.S. president goes.

But the first ministers' attempt to display unity in a potential trade war with the U.S. was soured after Alberta Premier Danielle Smith declared she won't stand for how the federal government and other leaders have refused to rule out slapping tariffs on Canadian fossil fuel exports.

Canadian business leaders prepare for Trump tariff announcement as early as Monday - but there will be exceptions, they predict

With Donald Trump set to take the oath of office Monday, the North American economy stands on the verge of a trade war.

But will the U.S. president-elect actually follow through on repeated threats of across-the-board, 25 per cent tariffs on Canadian imports on Day One?

The answer, say business groups, trade experts and economists, is probably not.

Everything you need to know about Trump's inauguration

At 12 p.m. Trump and J.D. Vance will be sworn in as the 47th president and 50th vice-president outside of the U.S. Capitol as part of an inauguration ceremony that happens every four years for every incoming president. (This year's inauguration will be the 60th in the country's history.)

While many are familiar with the photos of presidents and vice-presidents bundled up in winter coats and scarves with their right hands raised to take their oaths of office, the swearing-in ceremony isn't the only thing that happens on Inauguration Day - and there are often events planned leading up to the day as well.

Here's everything you need to know about Monday's ceremony and festivities

Who is attending the inauguration?

With incoming U.S. president Donald Trump's inauguration days away, much may be gleaned about the upcoming administration by who's on the guest list, who isn't - and who declined to take part.

From what we know so far, the ceremony on Monday will be attended by former presidents, government officials, tech billionaires and a smattering of far-right leaders including Argentinian President Javier Milei and U.K. politician Nigel Farage.

Notably, former first lady Michelle Obama will be skipping the ceremony, according to her office. Her husband, former president Barack Obama, has confirmed his attendance.

Is Donald Trump's inauguration on Martin Luther King Jr. Day?

Yes, this year, Inauguration Day falls on the same day as Martin Luther King Jr. Day.

What time is the inauguration?

Donald Trump's presidential inauguration is scheduled to begin at noon (EST).

Trump to rally in D.C. ahead of inauguration

Donald Trump is expected to hold a big Washington rally the day before he's sworn in as the nation's 47th president.

The victory rally, as it's being billed, will be held at the Capitol One Arena in the District of Columbia on Jan. 19. Trump has always preferred rally-style events where he can freewheel and joke with his supporters. He'll be inaugurated in a formal ceremony at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 20th.

"This is President Trump's VICTORY RALLY the DAY before being sworn in as the 47th President - the crowd needs to be HUGE!" read an email to supporters advertising the event.

U.S. Capitol flags raised to full height for Trump's inauguration

The Republican leader's decision means that President-elect Donald Trump will not take the oath of office for his second term under a half-staff flag, a prospect that he had previously complained about.

It mirrors actions taken in recent days by some Republican governors who have announced that flags in their states would be raised on Inauguration Day to mark Trump's second term.

Will Michelle Obama attend the inauguration?

Former first lady Michelle Obama will skip the inauguration of President-elect Donald Trump, the second time in two weeks that she is not attending a gathering of former U.S. leaders and their spouses, but former Presidents Barack Obama, George W. Bush and Bill Clinton will be there. Laura Bush and former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton will join their husbands for the Jan. 20 swearing-in ceremony at the Capitol, representatives said.

President-elect Donald Trump's inauguration for his second presidential term took place in Washington, D.C. on Monday. Trump has officially become the 47th president of the United States and Vice-President-elect JD Vance has also take the oath of office. Follow the Star's live updates all day.

4:40 p.m. Environment minister says Donald Trump pulling out of Paris pact is "deplorable"

Environment Minister Steven Guilbeault says it's "deplorable" that President Donald Trump is again pulling the U.S. out of the 2015 Paris Accord.

He says it's "quite ironic" that President Trump is abandoning the global environmental pact while California is experiencing one of its worst forest fire seasons ever.

Guilbeault also points out it's not the first time Trump has taken the U.S. out of the accord - he did the same thing during his first term in the Oval Office.

The environment minister says the nearly 200 nations still in the pact will forge ahead in the fight against climate change without the U.S. on board.

Read the full story.

3:28 p.m. Elon Musk draws fire for salute

Elon Musk delivered a "odd-looking salute" on live television during his speech at Trump's inaugural parade, pounding his chest and shooting out his right arm in a familiar manner. He then turned around and repeated the gesture: "My heart goes out to you," he said.

"You saw him come out with that odd-looking salute," CNN anchor Erin Burnett noted during the broadcast.

The ensuing fervour on social media was more blunt: "Yes, that is very clearly a Nazi salute," one X user wrote.

3:05 p.m. Trump may pardon Jan. 6 convicts: reports

Trump is reportedly preparing to issue sweeping pardons for the defendants charged in the Jan. 6 attack on the U.S. Capitol, according to ABC News.

This would include commuting the sentences of hundreds of his followers convicted of assaulting law enforcement on that day, and full pardons to those not charged with engaging with violence, ABC reports, citing unnamed sources.

It's possible the plans could change or be scaled back before they're formally signed.

2:51 p.m. DOGE hit by lawsuits

The nascent Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE), to be headed by Trump ally Elon Musk, has reportedly been hit by a flurry of lawsuits mere minutes after Trump's inauguration.

Several of the suits accused the Trump administration of flouting transparency rules that required DOGE to disclose its hiring practices and interactions, and seek to bar the government from taking on any of the advisory group's recommendations until it complies with the law.

The suits come from public interest law firm National Security Counselors; Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics, representing a coalition of teachers' unions and veterans' organizations; and a trio of organizations including nonprofit Public Citizen, the American Federation of Government Employees and the State Democracy Defenders Fund.

2:43 p.m. Wayne Gretzky, Janet Gretzky among celebrities at Trump inauguration

Wayne and Janet Gretzky were among the many celebrities and high profile public figures who attended Trump's inauguration on Monday Morning.

"We are so very proud," Janet wrote under a photo alongside Wayne shared on Instagram. "We love America, We love Canada. God Bless everyone!"

The Great One's friendly relationship with Trump has been under scrutiny in recent weeks. In December, the president-elect told his followers on Truth Social that he had encouraged Gretzky to run for office: "I said, 'Wayne, why don't you run for prime minister of Canada, soon to be known as the governor of Canada - you would win easily, you wouldn't even have to campaign.' He had no interest," Trump wrote.

2:38 p.m. Danielle Smith urges Canadian officials to allay Trump concerns

Alberta Premier Danielle Smith issued a statement saying she was "pleased" but that "despite the promising news today, the threat of U.S. tariffs is still very real."

In a post on X, Smith urged Canadian federal and provincial leaders to stop talking about "retaliatory measures including export tariffs or cutting off energy to the U.S." and instead allay Trump's concerns through tighter border security, more defence spending, tougher immigration policies, and the repeal of "anti-energy" policies.

2:29 p.m. A wave of Trump-demanded departures hits senior leadership at the State Department

A large number of senior career diplomats who served in politically appointed top leadership positions at the State Department have left their posts at the demand of the incoming Trump administration, which plans to install its own people in those positions, according to current and outgoing U.S. officials.

Personnel changes in the senior ranks of the department, like those at all federal agencies, are not uncommon after a presidential election, and career officials serving in those roles are required, just as non-career political appointees, to submit letters of resignation before an incoming administration takes office.

Read the full story.

2:22 p.m. Biden reacts to Trump's speech

Biden reacted to Trump's inaugural address in his first speech as a former president at Joint Base Andrews just before leaving for California.

"We heard the inaugural address today - you know, we got a lot more to do," he said, before crossing himself to laughter from the crowd and his former staffers.

"No president gets to choose the moment they enter history. But they get to choose the team they enter history with. And we chose the best damn team in the world," he said. "We're leaving office. But we're not leaving the fight."

Biden exited to chants of "thank you, Joe."

2:06 p.m. "Nelk Boys" co-founder attends with Conor McGregor and Jake and Logan Paul

Internet personality Kyle Forgeard - the Mississauga-born co-founder of the absurdly popular YouTube channel "Nelk Boys" - shared a video on Instagram Monday en route to Trump's inauguration alongside influencers Jake and Logan Paul and Irish MMA fighter Conor McGregor.

The Nelk Boys started out as a prank show, but has in recent years become a platform known for promoting right-wing political causes. In 2022, Forbes named Forgeard as one of the top social media influencers under 30.

McGregor was recently sued for alleged sexual battery over an incident that took place at the 2023 NBA finals. In November of last year, a civil court jury in Ireland awarded 250,000 euros to a woman who said she was "brutally raped and battered" by the MMA fighter.

2 p.m. (Updated) Trump rebuffs Biden's pardons

Trump rebuffed Biden's pardons of his family members and others including Anthony Fauci, Liz Cheney and the committee investigating the January 6 insurrection in a rambling speech at Emancipation Hall, claiming that some of the people were "very, very guilty of very bad crimes."

These included the January 6th Unselect Committee, who he claimed "deleted all the information on Nancy Pelosi having turned down the offer of 10,000 soldiers" at the event. It's a repeated claim of Trump's that the committee found no evidence of ever happening.

Trump also claimed Biden pardoned "33 murderers" and denounced Cheney as a "crying lunatic."

Biden commuted the sentences of 37 people facing the death sentence. They must still serve life in prison without parole - they were not "pardoned" as Trump implied.

Earlier Monday, Biden also commuted the life sentence of Native American activist Leonard Peltier, who was convicted of murdering two FBI agents. Peltier will serve out the rest of his sentence in home confinement.

Read the full transcript of Trump's speech.

1:54 p.m. Senator John Fetterman keeps it casual

Trump's official swearing-in ceremony was moved inside the Capitol Rotunda due to forecasts of "intense cold weather," with temperatures dipping below zero around noon. But the chilly air did not seem to bother Democratic Senator John Fetterman, who arrived at the Capitol wearing a baggy pair of shorts and a black Carhartt hoodie. Though Fetterman is known for his casual attire, he was spotted wearing a suit for Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's address to Congress last summer.

1:45 p.m. Donald Trump becomes U.S. president for a second time

Donald Trump, the populist disrupter who has vowed political revenge, the mass deportation of "animals" from other countries, and the use of tariffs to win influence and prosperity from abroad - including, perhaps, from Canada - is now the 47th president of the United States.

At a ceremony inside the rotunda of the domed U.S. Capitol Building, where his supporters rioted over the lost presidential election four years ago, Trump officially returned to power at noon on Monday. The moment capped a political restoration that saw Trump survive a criminal conviction, get past investigations into his alleged role in seeking to overturn the 2020 presidential election, and clinch expanded support from American voters in winning November's presidential vote.

"The golden age of America begins right now," said Trump, 78, in his second inaugural address.

Read the full story from the Star's Alex Ballingall

1:31 p.m. Trump is giving a speech to an inauguration crowd after being introduced by JD Vance.

"You're a younger, far more beautiful audience than the one I just spoke to," he joked. "I want to keep it off the record."

Trump also addressed Biden's pre-emptive pardons of his family members and others hours before the inauguration, noting they were "very, very guilty of very bad crimes."

1:30 p.m. A group of men clad in the garb of the Proud Boys marched through the streets of Washington shortly after Trump was sworn in. A handful of counter protesters yelled through megaphones that they were "losers."

1:25 p.m. Trump administration shuts down CBP One

The new Trump administration has already shut down CBP One, a government mobile app that previously helped migrants submit information and schedule appointments at ports of entry.

"Effective January 20, 2025, the functionalities of CBP One that previously allowed undocumented aliens to submit advance information and schedule appointments at eight southwest border ports of entry is no longer available, and existing appointments have been cancelled," an alert on the app's website reads.

Roughly 270,000 Mexican migrants were waiting to get an appointment through the app before it shuttered, CBS reports. As of Jan. 16, nearly 919,000 migrants were allowed into the States through the app.

1:16 p.m. Trudeau congratulates Trump

In a social media post, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau congratulated Trump on his inauguration. "We have the chance to work together again -- to create more jobs and prosperity for both our nations," Trudeau said.

In his speech, Trump did not mention Canada but reiterated his threat of tariffs on foreign nations. Trump had previously threatened 25 per cent tariffs against Canada.

FBI acting chief Paul Abbate says he's retiring

Paul Abbate, who became the FBI's acting director following the departure of Christopher Wray, is retiring from the bureau, according to an email he sent to senior executives that was obtained by The Associated Press on Monday.

Abbate had been expected to run the FBI while Senate confirmation proceedings get underway for Kash Patel, who is President Donald Trump's pick for director. But with Abbate's retirement effective Monday, when Trump took office, it was not immediately clear who would fill that role.

1:02 p.m. Government site gets makeover

The whitehouse.gov website got a makeover, welcoming visitors with a video glorifying Trump to soaring orchestral music before giving way to a landing page boasting that "America is back" in large lettering and an image of Trump.

"Every single day I will be fighting for you with every breath in my body," an accompanying caption reads. "I will not rest until we have delivered the strong, safe and prosperous America that our children deserve and that you deserve. This will truly be the golden age of America."

12:43 p.m. Carrie Underwood's performance beset by technical difficulties

Carrie Underwood's highly-anticipated performance at Trump's inauguration did not exactly go as planned.

After being introduced, the Grammy-winning country singer stood in awkward silence caused by technical difficulties as she waited for the musical track to begin. After about a minute, Underwood could be seen mouthing the words "I can just sing it," before requesting that the audience "help me out here." She then proceeded to perform the song a cappella without further issue.

An eight-time Grammy winner, Underwood, 41, is the highest profile artist slated to perform at Trump's inauguration. Her decision to perform at the inauguration was met with significant negative reactions from her fans, particularly her LGBTQ+ fans. Underwood has not publicly responded to those criticisms.

12:54 p.m. What did Melania Trump wear?

Incoming First Lady Melania Trump, who was mostly shunned by America's fashion establishment during her husband's last term in office, arrived at the church service ahead of her husband's second inauguration in a slim-fit navy silk-and-wool coat and skirt set by American designer Adam Lippes.

Notably, she accessorized it with a flat-brimmed, low-slung hat with white trim by Eric Javits, an American milliner since the 1980s with celebrity clients including Dua Lipa and Lady Gaga. Sitting low on her face Spy vs. Spy-style, the hat is destined to become an instant meme, while preventing the cameras from catching any accidental facial expressions-Melania has been captured seemingly giving side-eye at events in the past.

The choice of Adam Lippes for her outfit seems calculated to show support for a smaller, independent fashion designer. Lippes, who worked for Oscar de la Renta before starting his own label a decade ago, specializes in American sportswear; his dresses run in the $3,000 to $4,000 range. For Trump's first inauguration, Melanie wore a light blue dress by heritage brand Ralph Lauren (also a favourite designer of the Biden family) that drew comparisons to Jackie Kennedy's style.

"Melania's look is restrained, classic, uniform like. It looks like a dramatic governess outfit," said Tracy Richardson, a Canadian image consultant who has dressed clients for the White House, Buckingham Palace, the Oscars, TIFF and the Junos. "The hat is dramatic. But she looks neat. We aren't distracted by what she is wearing." Leanne Delap/Special to the Star

12:53 p.m. Trump stops short of immediately imposing Canadian tariffs

U.S. President Donald Trump has stopped short of immediately imposing his threatened 25-percent tariff on Canadian and Mexican goods.

But in his inaugural address minutes after taking office, Trump left no doubt he has foreign manufacturers and America's allies and competitors in his crosshairs.

He vowed he would set up a new agency to collect tariff revenues, and that he will fill American coffers with tariff and tax revenue from foreign countries, saying he was "saved by God to make America great again."

Trump declared a series of national emergencies to deploy soldiers to the Mexican border, ramp up oil drilling, end electric vehicle mandates, and began what he called "an overhaul" of U.S. trade relations.

12:44 p.m. Trump finished his speech by reiterating his hopes to be remembered as a peacemaker, assuring that a new American golden age had begun.

"Nothing will stand in our way because we are Americans, the future is ours, and our golden age has just begun," Trump finished to raucous cheers and a standing ovation.

12:42 p.m. "We stand on the verge of the four greatest years in American history," Trump says. "I am with you, I will fight for you, and I will win for you. We're going to win like never before."

12:40 p.m. Many people thought it was impossible for me to stage such a historic political comeback. But as you see today, here I am. The American people have spoken," Trump said to a standing ovation.

12:38 p.m. (updated) Trump is now running through a litany of promises for his administration, including taking back the Panama Canal, renaming the Gulf of Mexico, imposing tariffs on foreign countries and ending government DEI policies. He also lashed out to efforts to limit climate change, vowing to "drill, baby, drill."

With Elon Musk, CEO of SpaceX, sitting only feet away, Trump promises that America will "pursue our manifest destiny into the stars" and send American astronauts to Mars.

"Many people thought it was impossible for me to stage such a historic political comeback. But as you see today, here I am. The American people have spoken," Trump said to a standing ovation.

12:27 p.m. (updated) Trump says he is overhauling the trade system to protect Americans. "We will tariff and tax foreign countries to enrich out citizens," he says, vowing to establish an "external revenue service" to collect this money. Trump has previously threatened to impose 25 per cent tariffs on Canadian goods.

Trump promised to immediately sign an executive order to "immediately stop all government censorship and bring back free speech to America."

Trump says it is the official policy of the U.S. government that there are only two genders.

Trump promises to reinstate any military members ejected for not being vaccinated, with full backpay.

He also reiterated his promise to end government DEI policies.

"A short time from now, we are going to be changing the name of the Gulf of Mexico to the Gulf of America," Trunp said.

12:26 p.m. (updated) Trump promises 'golden age of America'

In his inaugural address, Trump promised the "golden age of America begins right now," reiterating his vow to "put America first."

"From this day forward, our country will flourish and be respected again all over the world," he said. "We will be the envy of every nation, and we will not allow ourselves to be taken advantage of any longer."

"I was saved by God to make America great again," Trump says.

Trump says today is "liberation day" for Americans, and hopes his election will be viewed as among the most influential in American history.

Trump says he will declare a national emergency at the Mexican-U.S. border, a line that draws a standing ovation from the rotunda -- with Biden, Harris, the Clintons and the Bushs notably sitting.

Trump vowed to end the Green New Deal and revoke the "electric vehicle mandate."

"In other words, you'll be able to buy the car of your choice. We will build automobiles in America again at a rate that nobody could have dreamt possible just a few years ago."

How much is Trump's crypto coin worth?

On Monday, Donald Trump's newly created cryptocurrency, a "meme coin" known as $TRUMP, soared to more than $8 billion dollars in market value, as of writing. Launched on Sunday, the collectible token, which has no inherent value, currently ranks third among other "meme coins" behind digital assets Dogecoin and Shiba Inu.

First Lady Melania Trump also launched a crypto coin, called $MELANIA,, on Sunday, which is currently trading just under $1 billion, behind other popular coins like "Pepe" and "Fartcoin."

Some crypto enthusiasts hailed the Trump meme coin's release, saying it's symbolic of the incoming president's support for an industry that felt unfairly targeted by the Biden administration. Trump has promised to usher in crypto-friendly regulations and picked crypto cheerleaders for key government positions.

Critics said the Trump meme coin could be a dangerous way for special interests and foreign governments to try and buy influence with the president.

How tall are Barron Trump and Donald Trump?

Since Trump was first elected, much ink has been spilled about the president's "large adult sons," Donald Jr. and Eric. But Trump's youngest child, Barron has largely evaded the spotlight.

That may be about to change, given that Barron is now 18 and looks looks like he could an up-and-coming shooting guard for Washington Wizards. Indeed, standing behind the president's podium at Monday's inauguration, the baby-faced Trump towered over the other attendees.

But exactly how tall is Barron? Google has him listed at 2.06 metres, which is almost 6 foot 8. However, he was listed at 6 foot 7 during his graduation from Oxbridge Academy in West Palm Beach last May. That's at least four inches taller than his father, who is listed at 6 foot 3, or 1.9 metres.

12:08 p.m. Both Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and Conservative leader Pierre Poilievre have been quiet so far on social media regarding Trump's inauguration.

Mark Carney and Christia Freeland, frontrunners in the Liberal Party's leadership race, have also not posted.

12:03 p.m. Trump and JD Vance sworn in

Trump was sworn in right after as his family watched, finishing to rapturous applause.

"I, Donald John Trump, do solemnly swear that I will faithfully execute the Office of President of the United States, and will to the best of my ability, preserve, protect and defend the Constitution of the United States. So help me God," Trump said in his oath as he was sworn in by Chief Justice John Roberts.

12:02 p.m. JD Vance, surrounded by his wife Usha and children Ewan, Vivek and Mirabel, is sworn in by Supreme Court justice Brett Kavanaugh. "Congratulations, Mr. Vice President," Kavanaugh says as the rotunda erupts in cheers.

JD Vance raised his right hand and recited his vow at 12:01 pm as he was sworn in by Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh as his wife Usha and three children watched on.

11:52 a.m. President-elect Donald Trump and his incoming vice president JD Vance are present in the U.S. Capitol Rotunda for the imminent swearing-in ceremony as past presidents, tech billionaires and foreign world leaders in attendance watch on.

11:50 a.m. Trump enters to cheers

Trump entered the rotunda to rousing cheers, shaking hands with Joe Biden and Apple CEO Tim Cook. He also gave an air kiss to wife Melania. Chants of "USA" broke out before Trump sat next to vice president-elect JD Vance.

11:47 a.m. Biden pardon family members

In the final minutes of his presidency, Joe Biden has pardoned the Biden family, his brothers James and Francis, sister-in-law Sara Jones, sister Valerie and brother-in-law John.

"My family has been subjected to unrelenting attacks and threats, motivated solely by a desire to hurt me-the worst kind of partisan politics," Biden said in a statement. "Unfortunately, I have no reason to believe these attacks will end."

Biden also commuted the life sentence of Leonard Peltier. The 80-year-old was convicted for the 1975 killings of two FBI agents during a standoff on a reservation in South Dakota.

"This commutation will enable Mr. Peltier to spend his remaining days in home confinement but will not pardon him for his underlying crimes," a White House statement said.

11:35 a.m. (updated) Guests arriving for the inauguration

Former president Barack Obama has arrived without former first lady Michelle Obama, who announced last week she would forego Monday's event.

Met with significant boos by the crowd, former Vice President Mike Pence, Former President Bill Clinton, and former first lady Hillary Clinton are also amongst the guests in attendance.

Tech titan and major Trump donor Elon Musk, who will be heading the new Department of Government Efficiency, has also arrived, alongside Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg and Apple CEO Tim Cook. Podcast host Joe Rogan has also been seen in attendance.

Argentine President Javier Milei and Italian Premier Giorgia Meloni have also been seen in the Rotunda, the first foreign leaders to attend the inauguration since 1874.

Trump's cabinet picks, including future secretary of state Marco Rubio and Pete Hegseth, the controversial pick for defence secretary, have also been seen at the capitol.

Everything you need to know about Trump's inauguration

At 12 p.m. Trump and J.D. Vance will be sworn in as the 47th president and 50th vice-president outside of the U.S. Capitol as part of an inauguration ceremony that happens every four years for every incoming president. (This year's inauguration will be the 60th in the country's history.)

While many are familiar with the photos of presidents and vice-presidents bundled up in winter coats and scarves with their right hands raised to take their oaths of office, the swearing-in ceremony isn't the only thing that happens on Inauguration Day - and there are often events planned leading up to the day as well.

Here's everything you need to know about Monday's ceremony and festivities

Who is attending the inauguration?

With incoming U.S. president Donald Trump's inauguration days away, much may be gleaned about the upcoming administration by who's on the guest list, who isn't - and who declined to take part.

From what we know so far, the ceremony on Monday will be attended by former presidents, government officials, tech billionaires and a smattering of far-right leaders including Argentinian President Javier Milei and U.K. politician Nigel Farage.

Notably, former first lady Michelle Obama will be skipping the ceremony, according to her office. Her husband, former president Barack Obama, has confirmed his attendance.

4:40 p.m. Environment minister says Donald Trump pulling out of Paris pact is "deplorable"

Environment Minister Steven Guilbeault says it's "deplorable" that President Donald Trump is again pulling the U.S. out of the 2015 Paris Accord.

He says it's "quite ironic" that President Trump is abandoning the global environmental pact while California is experiencing one of its worst forest fire seasons ever.

Guilbeault also points out it's not the first time Trump has taken the U.S. out of the accord - he did the same thing during his first term in the Oval Office.

The environment minister says the nearly 200 nations still in the pact will forge ahead in the fight against climate change without the U.S. on board.

3:28 p.m. Elon Musk draws fire for salute

Elon Musk delivered a "odd-looking salute" on live television during his speech at Trump's inaugural parade, pounding his chest and shooting out his right arm in a familiar manner. He then turned around and repeated the gesture: "My heart goes out to you," he said.

"You saw him come out with that odd-looking salute," CNN anchor Erin Burnett noted during the broadcast.

The ensuing fervour on social media was more blunt: "Yes, that is very clearly a Nazi salute," one X user wrote.

3:05 p.m. Trump may pardon Jan. 6 convicts: reports

Trump is reportedly preparing to issue sweeping pardons for the defendants charged in the Jan. 6 attack on the U.S. Capitol, according to ABC News.

This would include commuting the sentences of hundreds of his followers convicted of assaulting law enforcement on that day, and full pardons to those not charged with engaging with violence, ABC reports, citing unnamed sources.

It's possible the plans could change or be scaled back before they're formally signed.

2:51 p.m. DOGE hit by lawsuits

The nascent Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE), to be headed by Trump ally Elon Musk, has reportedly been hit by a flurry of lawsuits mere minutes after Trump's inauguration.

Several of the suits accused the Trump administration of flouting transparency rules that required DOGE to disclose its hiring practices and interactions, and seek to bar the government from taking on any of the advisory group's recommendations until it complies with the law.

The suits come from public interest law firm National Security Counselors; Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics, representing a coalition of teachers' unions and veterans' organizations; and a trio of organizations including nonprofit Public Citizen, the American Federation of Government Employees and the State Democracy Defenders Fund.

2:43 p.m. Wayne Gretzky, Janet Gretzky among celebrities at Trump inauguration

Wayne and Janet Gretzky were among the many celebrities and high profile public figures who attended Trump's inauguration on Monday Morning.

"We are so very proud," Janet wrote under a photo alongside Wayne shared on Instagram. "We love America, We love Canada. God Bless everyone!"

The Great One's friendly relationship with Trump has been under scrutiny in recent weeks. In December, the president-elect told his followers on Truth Social that he had encouraged Gretzky to run for office: "I said, 'Wayne, why don't you run for prime minister of Canada, soon to be known as the governor of Canada - you would win easily, you wouldn't even have to campaign.' Biden reacted to Trump's inaugural address in his first speech as a former president at Joint Base Andrews just before leaving for California.

Internet personality Kyle Forgeard - the Mississauga-born co-founder of the absurdly popular YouTube channel "Nelk Boys" - shared a video on Instagram Monday en route to Trump's inauguration alongside influencers Jake and Logan Paul and Irish MMA fighter Conor McGregor.

The Nelk Boys started out as a prank show, but has in recent years become a platform known for promoting right-wing political causes. In 2022, Forbes named Forgeard as one of the top social media influencers under 30.

McGregor was recently sued for alleged sexual battery over an incident that took place at the 2023 NBA finals. In November of last year, a civil court jury in Ireland awarded 250,000 euros to a woman who said she was "brutally raped and battered" by the MMA fighter.

2 p.m. (Updated) Trump rebuffs Biden's pardons

Trump rebuffed Biden's pardons of his family members and others including Anthony Fauci, Liz Cheney and the committee investigating the January 6 insurrection in a rambling speech at Emancipation Hall, claiming that some of the people were "very, very guilty of very bad crimes."

These included the January 6th Unselect Committee, who he claimed "deleted all the information on Nancy Pelosi having turned down the offer of 10,000 soldiers" at the event. It's a repeated claim of Trump's that the committee found no evidence of ever happening.

Trump also claimed Biden pardoned "33 murderers" and denounced Cheney as a "crying lunatic."

Biden commuted the sentences of 37 people facing the death sentence. They must still serve life in prison without parole - they were not "pardoned" as Trump implied.

Earlier Monday, Biden also commuted the life sentence of Native American activist Leonard Peltier, who was convicted of murdering two FBI agents. Peltier will serve out the rest of his sentence in home confinement.

1:45 p.m. Donald Trump becomes U.S. president for a second time

Read the full story from the Star's Kevin Jiang

Is Donald Trump's inauguration on Martin Luther King Jr. Day?

Yes, this year, Inauguration Day falls on the same day as Martin Luther King Jr. Day.

What time is the inauguration?

Donald Trump's presidential inauguration is scheduled to begin at noon (EST).

Trump to rally in D.C. ahead of inauguration

Donald Trump is expected to hold a big Washington rally the day before he's sworn in as the nation's 47th president.

The victory rally, as it's being billed, will be held at the Capitol One Arena in the District of Columbia on Jan. 19. Trump has always preferred rally-style events where he can freewheel and joke with his supporters. He'll be inaugurated in a formal ceremony at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 20th.

"This is President Trump's VICTORY RALLY the DAY before being sworn in as the 47th President - the crowd needs to be HUGE!" read an email to supporters advertising the event.

Read the full story from the Associated Press

U.S. Capitol flags raised to full height for Trump's inauguration

House Speaker Mike Johnson on Tuesday ordered that flags at the U.S. Capitol be raised to their full height on Inauguration Day, pausing a 30-day flag-lowering order following the death of former President Jimmy Carter.

The Republican leader's decision means that President-elect Donald Trump will not take the oath of office for his second term under a half-staff flag, a prospect that he had previously complained about.

It mirrors actions taken in recent days by some Republican governors who have announced that flags in their states would be raised on Inauguration Day to mark Trump's second term.

Read the full story from the Associated Press

Will Michelle Obama attend the inauguration?

Former first lady Michelle Obama will skip the inauguration of President-elect Donald Trump, the second time in two weeks that she is not attending a gathering of former U.S. leaders and their spouses, but former Presidents Barack Obama, George W. Bush and Bill Clinton will be there. Laura Bush and former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton will join their husbands for the Jan. 20 swearing-in ceremony at the Capitol, representatives said.

President-elect Donald Trump's inauguration for his second presidential term took place in Washington, D.C. on Monday. Trump has officially become the 47th president of the United States and Vice-President-elect JD Vance has also take the oath of office. Follow the Star's live updates all day.

4:40 p.m. Environment minister says Donald Trump pulling out of Paris pact is "deplorable"

Environment Minister Steven Guilbeault says it's "deplorable" that President Donald Trump is again pulling the U.S. out of the 2015 Paris Accord.

He says it's "quite ironic" that President Trump is abandoning the global environmental pact while California is experiencing one of its worst forest fire seasons ever.

Guilbeault also points out it's not the first time Trump has taken the U.S. out of the accord - he did the same thing during his first term in the Oval Office.

The environment minister says the nearly 200 nations still in the pact will forge ahead in the fight against climate change without the U.S. on board.

Read the full story.

3:28 p.m. Elon Musk draws fire for salute

Elon Musk delivered a "odd-looking salute" on live television during his speech at Trump's inaugural parade, pounding his chest and shooting out his right arm in a familiar manner. He then turned around and repeated the gesture: "My heart goes out to you," he said.

"You saw him come out with that odd-looking salute," CNN anchor Erin Burnett noted during the broadcast.

The ensuing fervour on social media was more blunt: "Yes, that is very clearly a Nazi salute," one X user wrote.

3:05 p.m. Trump may pardon Jan. 6 convicts: reports

Trump is reportedly preparing to issue sweeping pardons for the defendants charged in the Jan. 6 attack on the U.S. Capitol, according to ABC News.

This would include commuting the sentences of hundreds of his followers convicted of assaulting law enforcement on that day, and full pardons to those not charged with engaging with violence, ABC reports, citing unnamed sources.

It's possible the plans could change or be scaled back before they're formally signed.

2:51 p.m. DOGE hit by lawsuits

The nascent Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE), to be headed by Trump ally Elon Musk, has reportedly been hit by a flurry of lawsuits mere minutes after Trump's inauguration.

Several of the suits accused the Trump administration of flouting transparency rules that required DOGE to disclose its hiring practices and interactions, and seek to bar the government from taking on any of the advisory group's recommendations until it complies with the law.

The suits come from public interest law firm National Security Counselors; Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics, representing a coalition of teachers' unions and veterans' organizations; and a trio of organizations including nonprofit Public Citizen, the American Federation of Government Employees and the State Democracy Defenders Fund.

2:43 p.m. Wayne Gretzky, Janet Gretzky among celebrities at Trump inauguration

Wayne and Janet Gretzky were among the many celebrities and high profile public figures who attended Trump's inauguration on Monday Morning.

"We are so very proud," Janet wrote under a photo alongside Wayne shared on Instagram. "We love America, We love Canada. God Bless everyone!"

The Great One's friendly relationship with Trump has been under scrutiny in recent weeks. In December, the president-elect told his followers on Truth Social that he had encouraged Gretzky to run for office: "I said, 'Wayne, why don't you run for prime minister of Canada, soon to be known as the governor of Canada - you would win easily, you wouldn't even have to campaign.' He had no interest," Trump wrote.

Doug Ford says a 'clear mandate' from Ontario voters is the best way to deal with Donald Trump

2:38 p.m. Danielle Smith urges Canadian officials to allay Trump concerns

Alberta Premier Danielle Smith issued a statement saying she was "pleased" but that "despite the promising news today, the threat of U.S. tariffs is still very real."

In a post on X, Smith urged Canadian federal and provincial leaders to stop talking about "retaliatory measures including export tariffs or cutting off energy to the U.S." and instead allay Trump's concerns through tighter border security, more defence spending, tougher immigration policies, and the repeal of "anti-energy" policies.

2:29 p.m. A wave of Trump-demanded departures hits senior leadership at the State Department

A large number of senior career diplomats who served in politically appointed top leadership positions at the State Department have left their posts at the demand of the incoming Trump administration, which plans to install its own people in those positions, according to current and outgoing U.S. officials.

Personnel changes in the senior ranks of the department, like those at all federal agencies, are not uncommon after a presidential election, and career officials serving in those roles are required, just as non-career political appointees, to submit letters of resignation before an incoming administration takes office.

Read the full story.

2:22 p.m. Biden reacts to Trump's speech

Biden reacted to Trump's inaugural address in his first speech as a former president at Joint Base Andrews just before leaving for California.

"We heard the inaugural address today - you know, we got a lot more to do," he said, before crossing himself to laughter from the crowd and his former staffers.

"No president gets to choose the moment they enter history. But they get to choose the team they enter history with. And we chose the best damn team in the world," he said. "We're leaving office. But we're not leaving the fight."

Biden exited to chants of "thank you, Joe."

2:06 p.m. "Nelk Boys" co-founder attends with Conor McGregor and Jake and Logan Paul

Internet personality Kyle Forgeard - the Mississauga-born co-founder of the absurdly popular YouTube channel "Nelk Boys" - shared a video on Instagram Monday en route to Trump's inauguration alongside influencers Jake and Logan Paul and Irish MMA fighter Conor McGregor.

The Nelk Boys started out as a prank show, but has in recent years become a platform known for promoting right-wing political causes. In 2022, Forbes named Forgeard as one of the top social media influencers under 30.

McGregor was recently sued for alleged sexual battery over an incident that took place at the 2023 NBA finals. In November of last year, a civil court jury in Ireland awarded 250,000 euros to a woman who said she was "brutally raped and battered" by the MMA fighter.

2 p.m. (Updated) Trump rebuffs Biden's pardons

Trump rebuffed Biden's pardons of his family members and others including Anthony Fauci, Liz Cheney and the committee investigating the January 6 insurrection in a rambling speech at Emancipation Hall, claiming that some of the people were "very, very guilty of very bad crimes."

These included the January 6th Unselect Committee, who he claimed "deleted all the information on Nancy Pelosi having turned down the offer of 10,000 soldiers" at the event. It's a repeated claim of Trump's that the committee found no evidence of ever happening.

Trump also claimed Biden pardoned "33 murderers" and denounced Cheney as a "crying lunatic."

Biden commuted the sentences of 37 people facing the death sentence. They must still serve life in prison without parole - they were not "pardoned" as Trump implied.

Earlier Monday, Biden also commuted the life sentence of Native American activist Leonard Peltier, who was convicted of murdering two FBI agents. Peltier will serve out the rest of his sentence in home confinement.

Read the full transcript of Trump's speech.

1:54 p.m. Senator John Fetterman keeps it casual

Trump's official swearing-in ceremony was moved inside the Capitol Rotunda due to forecasts of "intense cold weather," with temperatures dipping below zero around noon. But the chilly air did not seem to bother Democratic Senator John Fetterman, who arrived at the Capitol wearing a baggy pair of shorts and a black Carhartt hoodie. Though Fetterman is known for his casual attire, he was spotted wearing a suit for Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's address to Congress last summer.

1:45 p.m. Donald Trump becomes U.S. president for a second time

Donald Trump, the populist disrupter who has vowed political revenge, the mass deportation of "animals" from other countries, and the use of tariffs to win influence and prosperity from abroad - including, perhaps, from Canada - is now the 47th president of the United States.

At a ceremony inside the rotunda of the domed U.S. Capitol Building, where his supporters rioted over the lost presidential election four years ago, Trump officially returned to power at noon on Monday. The moment capped a political restoration that saw Trump survive a criminal conviction, get past investigations into his alleged role in seeking to overturn the 2020 presidential election, and clinch expanded support from American voters in winning November's presidential vote.

"The golden age of America begins right now," said Trump, 78, in his second inaugural address.

Read the full story from the Star's Alex Ballingall

1:31 p.m. Trump is giving a speech to an inauguration crowd after being introduced by JD Vance.

"You're a younger, far more beautiful audience than the one I just spoke to," he joked. "I want to keep it off the record."

Trump also addressed Biden's pre-emptive pardons of his family members and others hours before the inauguration, noting they were "very, very guilty of very bad crimes."

1:30 p.m. A group of men clad in the garb of the Proud Boys marched through the streets of Washington shortly after Trump was sworn in. A handful of counter protesters yelled through megaphones that they were "losers."

1:25 p.m. Trump administration shuts down CBP One

The new Trump administration has already shut down CBP One, a government mobile app that previously helped migrants submit information and schedule appointments at ports of entry.

"Effective January 20, 2025, the functionalities of CBP One that previously allowed undocumented aliens to submit advance information and schedule appointments at eight southwest border ports of entry is no longer available, and existing appointments have been cancelled," an alert on the app's website reads.

Roughly 270,000 Mexican migrants were waiting to get an appointment through the app before it shuttered, CBS reports. As of Jan. 16, nearly 919,000 migrants were allowed into the States through the app.

1:16 p.m. Trudeau congratulates Trump

In a social media post, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau congratulated Trump on his inauguration. "We have the chance to work together again -- to create more jobs and prosperity for both our nations," Trudeau said.

In his speech, Trump did not mention Canada but reiterated his threat of tariffs on foreign nations. Trump had previously threatened 25 per cent tariffs against Canada.

FBI acting chief Paul Abbate says he's retiring

Paul Abbate, who became the FBI's acting director following the departure of Christopher Wray, is retiring from the bureau, according to an email he sent to senior executives that was obtained by The Associated Press on Monday.

Abbate had been expected to run the FBI while Senate confirmation proceedings get underway for Kash Patel, who is President Donald Trump's pick for director. But with Abbate's retirement effective Monday, when Trump took office, it was not immediately clear who would fill that role.

1:02 p.m. Government site gets makeover

The whitehouse.gov website got a makeover, welcoming visitors with a video glorifying Trump to soaring orchestral music before giving way to a landing page boasting that "America is back" in large lettering and an image of Trump.

"Every single day I will be fighting for you with every breath in my body," an accompanying caption reads. "I will not rest until we have delivered the strong, safe and prosperous America that our children deserve and that you deserve. This will truly be the golden age of America."

12:43 p.m. Carrie Underwood's performance beset by technical difficulties

Carrie Underwood's highly-anticipated performance at Trump's inauguration did not exactly go as planned.

After being introduced, the Grammy-winning country singer stood in awkward silence caused by technical difficulties as she waited for the musical track to begin. After about a minute, Underwood could be seen mouthing the words "I can just sing it," before requesting that the audience "help me out here." She then proceeded to perform the song a cappella without further issue.

An eight-time Grammy winner, Underwood, 41, is the highest profile artist slated to perform at Trump's inauguration. Her decision to perform at the inauguration was met with significant negative reactions from her fans, particularly her LGBTQ+ fans. Underwood has not publicly responded to those criticisms.

12:54 p.m. What did Melania Trump wear?

Incoming First Lady Melania Trump, who was mostly shunned by America's fashion establishment during her husband's last term in office, arrived at the church service ahead of her husband's second inauguration in a slim-fit navy silk-and-wool coat and skirt set by American designer Adam Lippes.

Notably, she accessorized it with a flat-brimmed, low-slung hat with white trim by Eric Javits, an American milliner since the 1980s with celebrity clients including Dua Lipa and Lady Gaga. Sitting low on her face Spy vs. Spy-style, the hat is destined to become an instant meme, while preventing the cameras from catching any accidental facial expressions-Melania has been captured seemingly giving side-eye at events in the past.

The choice of Adam Lippes for her outfit seems calculated to show support for a smaller, independent fashion designer. Lippes, who worked for Oscar de la Renta before starting his own label a decade ago, specializes in American sportswear; his dresses run in the $3,000 to $4,000 range. For Trump's first inauguration, Melanie wore a light blue dress by heritage brand Ralph Lauren (also a favourite designer of the Biden family) that drew comparisons to Jackie Kennedy's style.

"Melania's look is restrained, classic, uniform like. It looks like a dramatic governess outfit," said Tracy Richardson, a Canadian image consultant who has dressed clients for the White House, Buckingham Palace, the Oscars, TIFF and the Junos. "The hat is dramatic. But she looks neat. We aren't distracted by what she is wearing." Leanne Delap/Special to the Star

12:53 p.m. Trump stops short of immediately imposing Canadian tariffs

U.S. President Donald Trump has stopped short of immediately imposing his threatened 25-percent tariff on Canadian and Mexican goods.

But in his inaugural address minutes after taking office, Trump left no doubt he has foreign manufacturers and America's allies and competitors in his crosshairs.

He vowed he would set up a new agency to collect tariff revenues, and that he will fill American coffers with tariff and tax revenue from foreign countries, saying he was "saved by God to make America great again."

Trump declared a series of national emergencies to deploy soldiers to the Mexican border, ramp up oil drilling, end electric vehicle mandates, and began what he called "an overhaul" of U.S. trade relations.

12:44 p.m. Trump finished his speech by reiterating his hopes to be remembered as a peacemaker, assuring that a new American golden age had begun.

"Nothing will stand in our way because we are Americans, the future is ours, and our golden age has just begun," Trump finished to raucous cheers and a standing ovation.

12:42 p.m. "We stand on the verge of the four greatest years in American history," Trump says. "I am with you, I will fight for you, and I will win for you. We're going to win like never before."

12:40 p.m. Many people thought it was impossible for me to stage such a historic political comeback. But as you see today, here I am. The American people have spoken," Trump said to a standing ovation.

12:38 p.m. (updated) Trump is now running through a litany of promises for his administration, including taking back the Panama Canal, renaming the Gulf of Mexico, imposing tariffs on foreign countries and ending government DEI policies. He also lashed out to efforts to limit climate change, vowing to "drill, baby, drill."

With Elon Musk, CEO of SpaceX, sitting only feet away, Trump promises that America will "pursue our manifest destiny into the stars" and send American astronauts to Mars.

"Many people thought it was impossible for me to stage such a historic political comeback. But as you see today, here I am. The American people have spoken," Trump said to a standing ovation.

12:27 p.m. (updated) Trump says he is overhauling the trade system to protect Americans. "We will tariff and tax foreign countries to enrich out citizens," he says, vowing to establish an "external revenue service" to collect this money. Trump has previously threatened to impose 25 per cent tariffs on Canadian goods.

Trump promised to immediately sign an executive order to "immediately stop all government censorship and bring back free speech to America."

Trump says it is the official policy of the U.S. government that there are only two genders.

Trump promises to reinstate any military members ejected for not being vaccinated, with full backpay.

He also reiterated his promise to end government DEI policies.

"A short time from now, we are going to be changing the name of the Gulf of Mexico to the Gulf of America," Trunp said.

12:26 p.m. (updated) Trump promises 'golden age of America'

In his inaugural address, Trump promised the "golden age of America begins right now," reiterating his vow to "put America first."

"From this day forward, our country will flourish and be respected again all over the world," he said. "We will be the envy of every nation, and we will not allow ourselves to be taken advantage of any longer."

"I was saved by God to make America great again," Trump says.

Trump says today is "liberation day" for Americans, and hopes his election will be viewed as among the most influential in American history.

Trump says he will declare a national emergency at the Mexican-U.S. border, a line that draws a standing ovation from the rotunda -- with Biden, Harris, the Clintons and the Bushs notably sitting.

Trump vowed to end the Green New Deal and revoke the "electric vehicle mandate."

"In other words, you'll be able to buy the car of your choice. We will build automobiles in America again at a rate that nobody could have dreamt possible just a few years ago."

How much is Trump's crypto coin worth?

On Monday, Donald Trump's newly created cryptocurrency, a "meme coin" known as $TRUMP, soared to more than $8 billion dollars in market value, as of writing. Launched on Sunday, the collectible token, which has no inherent value, currently ranks third among other "meme coins" behind digital assets Dogecoin and Shiba Inu.

First Lady Melania Trump also launched a crypto coin, called $MELANIA,, on Sunday, which is currently trading just under $1 billion, behind other popular coins like "Pepe" and "Fartcoin."

Some crypto enthusiasts hailed the Trump meme coin's release, saying it's symbolic of the incoming president's support for an industry that felt unfairly targeted by the Biden administration. Trump has promised to usher in crypto-friendly regulations and picked crypto cheerleaders for key government positions.

Critics said the Trump meme coin could be a dangerous way for special interests and foreign governments to try and buy influence with the president.

How tall are Barron Trump and Donald Trump?

Since Trump was first elected, much ink has been spilled about the president's "large adult sons," Donald Jr. and Eric. But Trump's youngest child, Barron has largely evaded the spotlight.

That may be about to change, given that Barron is now 18 and looks looks like he could an up-and-coming shooting guard for Washington Wizards. Indeed, standing behind the president's podium at Monday's inauguration, the baby-faced Trump towered over the other attendees.

But exactly how tall is Barron? Google has him listed at 2.06 metres, which is almost 6 foot 8. However, he was listed at 6 foot 7 during his graduation from Oxbridge Academy in West Palm Beach last May. That's at least four inches taller than his father, who is listed at 6 foot 3, or 1.9 metres.

12:08 p.m. Both Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and Conservative leader Pierre Poilievre have been quiet so far on social media regarding Trump's inauguration.

Mark Carney and Christia Freeland, frontrunners in the Liberal Party's leadership race, have also not posted.

12:03 p.m. Trump and JD Vance sworn in

Trump was sworn in right after as his family watched, finishing to rapturous applause.

"I, Donald John Trump, do solemnly swear that I will faithfully execute the Office of President of the United States, and will to the best of my ability, preserve, protect and defend the Constitution of the United States. So help me God," Trump said in his oath as he was sworn in by Chief Justice John Roberts.

12:02 p.m. JD Vance, surrounded by his wife Usha and children Ewan, Vivek and Mirabel, is sworn in by Supreme Court justice Brett Kavanaugh. "Congratulations, Mr. Vice President," Kavanaugh says as the rotunda erupts in cheers.

JD Vance raised his right hand and recited his vow at 12:01 pm as he was sworn in by Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh as his wife Usha and three children watched on.

11:52 a.m. President-elect Donald Trump and his incoming vice president JD Vance are present in the U.S. Capitol Rotunda for the imminent swearing-in ceremony as past presidents, tech billionaires and foreign world leaders in attendance watch on.

Catch the ceremony and Trump's inaugural address live here

11:50 a.m. Trump enters to cheers

Trump entered the rotunda to rousing cheers, shaking hands with Joe Biden and Apple CEO Tim Cook. He also gave an air kiss to wife Melania. Chants of "USA" broke out before Trump sat next to vice president-elect JD Vance.

11:47 a.m. Biden pardon family members

In the final minutes of his presidency, Joe Biden has pardoned the Biden family, his brothers James and Francis, sister-in-law Sara Jones, sister Valerie and brother-in-law John.

"My family has been subjected to unrelenting attacks and threats, motivated solely by a desire to hurt me-the worst kind of partisan politics," Biden said in a statement. "Unfortunately, I have no reason to believe these attacks will end."

Biden also commuted the life sentence of Leonard Peltier. The 80-year-old was convicted for the 1975 killings of two FBI agents during a standoff on a reservation in South Dakota.

"This commutation will enable Mr. Peltier to spend his remaining days in home confinement but will not pardon him for his underlying crimes," a White House statement said.

11:40 a.m. The crowd errupts in cheers for JD Vance.

11:35 a.m. (updated) Guests arriving for the inauguration

Guests have arrived at the U.S. Capitol for the inauguration, which has been moved indoors due freezing temperatures brought by the Polar Vortex.

Former president Barack Obama has arrived without former first lady Michelle Obama, who announced last week she would forego Monday's event.

Met with significant boos by the crowd, former Vice President Mike Pence, Former President Bill Clinton, and former first lady Hillary Clinton are also amongst the guests in attendance.

Tech titan and major Trump donor Elon Musk, who will be heading the new Department of Government Efficiency, has also arrived, alongside Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg and Apple CEO Tim Cook. Podcast host Joe Rogan has also been seen in attendance.

Argentine President Javier Milei and Italian Premier Giorgia Meloni have also been seen in the Rotunda, the first foreign leaders to attend the inauguration since 1874.

Trump's cabinet picks, including future secretary of state Marco Rubio and Pete Hegseth, the controversial pick for defence secretary, have also been seen at the capitol.

11:32 a.m. Trump will be the oldest president ever inaugurated

At 78 years and 220 days old, Trump is five months older than Joe Biden when he was inaugurated in 2021.

Meanwhile, at 40 years old, JD Vance will be the third-youngest vice president in U.S. history.

11:30 a.m. Canada's Industry Minister Francois-Philippe Champagne was inside the Capitol building, attending the inauguration, watching the swearing-in with a number of Republican governors from Emancipation Hall, an overflow room, where the ceremony was shown on a big screen.

How did Trump spend his morning?

Trump kicked off his morning Monday with a pre-inauguration visit to St. John's Church. Among those in attendance were several billionaires and tech tycoons, including Amazon founder Jeff Bezos (net worth $239.4 billion (U.S.), Meta founder Mark Zuckerberg (net worth $211.8 billion (U.S.), Apple CEO Tim Cook (net worth $2.2 billion (U.S.) and Google CEO Sundar Pichai (net worth $2.1 billion (U.S.).

Among the other notable figures spotted at the church were media tycoon Rupert Murdoch (net worth $22.2 billion (U.S.), plus FIFA president Gianni Infantino. Former UK Conservative Prime Minister Boris Johnson and Javier Milei, the ultraconservative president of Argentina were also in attendance.

11:20 a.m. Who will swear in Trump?

Chief Justice John Roberts will swear in Trump as president. Brett Kavanaugh will swear in JD Vance as vice president.

11:18 a.m. George Bush has entered the rotunda, as has Barack Obama.

11:12 a.m. Trump does the 'Trump dance' during Village People performance

The Village People, a campy disco group, known for their goofy lyrics and problematic costumes, performed their hit song "Y.M.C.A." on stage with Trump on Sunday - assless chaps, Native American headdresses and all. The song has become a staple at Trump rallies - you've likely seen the President-elect's awkward, jerky dance moves, which first went viral during his 2020 election campaign. Since then, the "Trump" dance has been embraced by Trump supporters, frat boys and several pro athletes, including San Francisco 49ers star Nick Bosa and U.S. men's soccer team captain Christian Pulisic.

Over the decades, the 1978 hit has been embraced by the gay community. However, according to Victor Willis, the band's litigious lead singer (and only remaining original member) has insisted the song is not a "gay anthem." In fact, he recently stated that he will take legal action against anyone who suggests it is.

11:10 a.m. Trump's children have entered the Rotunda.

11:08 a.m. Putin congratulates Trump

Russian President Vladimir Putin congratulated Trump on his win earlier Monday morning during a televised meeting of Russia's Security Council.

"We see the statements by the newly elected president of the United States and members of his team about the desire to restore direct contacts with Russia," Putin said. "We also hear his statement about the need to do everything possible to prevent World War Three.

"We of course welcome this attitude and congratulate the elected president of the United States of America on taking office."

Canada bracing for Donald Trump's decision amid reports 25 per cent tariffs not immediately on the table

The Canadian government has not received any official confirmation that incoming U.S. President Donald Trump will not impose tariffs on Canadian products, as threatened.

Two senior Canadian officials said Monday the government was still waiting for official word that would confirm reports by the Wall Street Journal and New York Times that Trump is instead going to order a trade deficit review which would include a study of the North American free-trade pact.

One official said it is encouraging if true that Trump's threatened 25 per cent tariffs on all Canadian goods is not immediately on the table.

A14Trudeau takes a stand against MetaPM says media giant degrading 'safety, well-being and communities that thrive in our democracy'Brieanna Charlebois The Canadian Press

WEST KELOWNA, B.C. Canada's dispute with Meta is a "test moment" for the country to stand against the social media giant that's making billions off people, but taking no responsibility for the well-being of communities it profits from, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said Friday.

Trudeau made his comments in West Kelowna, one of several B.C. communities involved in evacuations of thousands of people last summer, while information about wildfires and escape routes were blocked on Meta's Facebook platform.

He called Meta an "irresponsible web giant," that had previously been making a huge profit sharing information from local journalists who worked hard to make sure people were properly informed.

"This is a test moment where countries are going to have to realize that either we stand up for journalism and the profession faced with internet giants that refuse to actually participate in it, or we bow down to them and allow them to make billions more dollars, while degrading the safety, well-being and communities that thrive in our democracy."

Meta has blocked Canadian news from Facebook and Instagram over the federal government's Online News Act, which seeks compensation for news outlets whose stories are used on the social media feeds.

Trudeau said he knows there are many people trying to figure out ways to keep everyone informed, especially in emergency situations, but countries need to stand up for journalism.

He noted his government had the same disagreement with Google, but the company "stepped up" with $100 million to make sure that local journalism was thriving.

B.C. Premier David Eby announced last month that the province had worked out an agreement with Meta and had received assurances that it would work with B.C. officials to deliver and amplify public information in case of natural disasters such as wildfires.

Trudeau was in West Kelowna last August, just days after a wildfire destroyed hundreds of homes. On Friday, the prime minister said he met with mayors and fires chiefs of those same communities, along with a number of families who lost homes in the B.C. Interior and who are still impacted by the situation.

"We know from the forecasts in Western and Northern Canada, because of the dry winter ... it is likely to be a very bad forest fire season," he said.

The Canadian Press
